results.title: Don't be let down
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1960 government film describes the regulations under the New South Wales Scaffolding and Lifts Act and how they apply in the building industry. Accompanied by an instructional narration, it surveys the correct manufacture, use and storage of wooden ladders in the industry. It outlines the dangers of improper use of ladders, including dramatic stagings of accidental falls through carelessness.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be incorrectly dressed
results.creator_credit: Ron Collins, Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1962 film demonstrates the need for various types of protective clothing and equipment when working with abrasives, welding, lead and chemicals. Accompanied by an instructional narration, the film shows footage of workers in various industries, and the need for protective glasses, face shields, respirators, gloves, footwear and clothing.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be cut up
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1959 film outlines the hazards associated with the metal trade industry. It emphasises the importance of fixed guards on machines including guillotines, bending brakes, power presses and emery wheels. The film is interspersed with title cards including the repeated ‘Accidents need not happen’ and features a voiceover narration dramatically warning against accidents. It is directed at both workers in the factory risking accident and disability, and employers risking loss of production and financial loss.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't be a fall guy
results.creator_credit: Ron Collins, Stan Murdoch, Reg Perier and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1962 instructional film demonstrates safety regulations on building sites in Sydney, New South Wales. Narrated by a didactic voiceover, the film dramatises the do’s and dont’s of construction sites, including good housekeeping, adequate lighting, head protection, guard rails, proper scaffolding and safety lines. It emphasises the risks of carelessness and overconfidence of builders working without proper safety equipment.

In order to demonstrate this, the film restages several accidents, including a man falling down an open lift shaft after the guard rail was removed by a fellow builder. The film also includes footage of riggers climbing steel frames on multi-story buildings without safety harnesses, in what would have been standard practice in this era.

Produced by the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Forward communications
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Stresses that Australia’s vast distances make an efficient system of communication most essential. Shows how the Post Office is maintaining our present communications system at a high level of efficiency and also how the heavy post-war demand for new telephones and exchanges is being met.

results.title: The Destruction of St. Patrick's College 1971
results.brief_description: The old St Patrick’s College was demolished to make way for an ecclesiastic office building. Professor Hartley Gratten, of the University of Texas considers, against the background of the demolition by Whelan the Wrecker, why Australians ignore their national heritage.

results.title: Depending on weather
results.brief_description: A driver’s safety depends on the reliability of their car and on their knowledge and experience. As winter approaches racing driver David Mackay checks his car’s reliability to face all weather conditions.

results.title: A Demonstration of basic film techniques
results.brief_description: Designed to serve as a practical aid for teachers presenting a course in film appreciation. Experience has shown that one of the first barriers to be broken down in such a course is the students’ ignorance of the fact that a film is MADE, that it is the result of conscious decision by the film maker. Teachers may use it to demonstrate the more common shots in film making. They may use it to establish the idea of film editing - the joining together of separate shots into a meaningful unit. The film’s deficiencies and faults should serve as valuable teaching points during discussion after the film.

results.title: Defensive riding techniques
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Motorcycle safety”.
Defensive riding is avoiding accidents by foreseeing possible dangers and taking appropriate action. Gives three short rules: firstly, try to anticipate and, therefore, avoid mistakes of other motorists; secondly, drive defensively, and heed all traffic rules and signals; thirdly, make sure you can be seen at all times.

results.title: Dear mum
results.creator_credit: Don Marley, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Cinesound Movietone
results.brief_description: A highly entertaining and at times funny film about the life of a young soldier in the army. He writes to tell his mum all the great things that happen in the army - like seeing the country; friendship; a lot of spare time and the satisfaction from working as a group.
